title: Linear Algebra stuff

Articles about Linear Algebra and related topics.
Linear Algebra : Introduction

title: Introduction to linear algebra
text:
The book : Linear Algebra and Optimization for Machine Learning


What is Linear Algebra ?
Linear Algebra is the study of linear operations on vector spaces.
What is a linear operation then …
Let \(V\) and \(W\) be vector spaces. A function \(f: V \rightarrow W\) is a linear map if for any two vectors \(\textbf{u}\) and \(\textbf{v}\) the mapping is operation preserving, that is, it satisfies these conditions:

Additivity : \(f(\textbf{u} + \textbf{v}) = f(\textbf{u}) + f(\textbf{v})\)
Homogeneity of scalar multiplication : \(f(c\textbf{u}) = c*f(\textbf{u})\)

For example :
$$ \[\begin{align*}
    \begin{split}
        \textbf{a} = [0, 1] \\
        \textbf{b} = [1 ,1] \\
        \text{The function } f(a,b) = (3a,b) \text{works since: }
    \end{split}


    f(a+b) = f([0,1] + [1,1]) = f([1,2]) = (3,2)
    f(a) + f(b) = [0,1] + [3,1] = [3,2]

    f(a + [3,3] ) = f([0,1] + [3,3]) = f([3,4]) = [9,4]
    equal to
    f(a + [3,3]) = f(a) + f([3,3]) = [0,1] + [9,3] = [9,4]


    It preserves the multiplication, for ex lambda = 2:
    f(\lambda * a) = f(2*[0,1]) = f([0,2]) = [0,2]
    Which is the same as :
    f(\lambda * a) = \lambda * f(a) = 2 * [0,1] = [0,2]

\end{align*}\] $$

title: Introduction to linear algebra
text:
What is Linear Algebra ?
Linear Algebra is the study of linear operations on vector spaces.
What is a linear operation then …
Let \(V\) and \(W\) be vector spaces. A function \(f: V \rightarrow W\) is a linear map if for any two vectors \(\textbf{u}\) and \(\textbf{v}\) the mapping is operation preserving, that is, it satisfies these conditions:

Additivity : \(f(\textbf{u} + \textbf{v}) = f(\textbf{u}) + f(\textbf{v})\)
Homogeneity of scalar multiplication : \(f(c\textbf{u}) = c*f(\textbf{u})\)

For example :
$$ \[\begin{align*}
    \begin{split}
        \textbf{a} = [0, 1] \\
        \textbf{b} = [1 ,1] \\
        \text{The function } f(a,b) = (3a,b) \text{works since: }
    \end{split}


    f(a+b) = f([0,1] + [1,1]) = f([1,2]) = (3,2)
    f(a) + f(b) = [0,1] + [3,1] = [3,2]

    f(a + [3,3] ) = f([0,1] + [3,3]) = f([3,4]) = [9,4]
    equal to
    f(a + [3,3]) = f(a) + f([3,3]) = [0,1] + [9,3] = [9,4]


    It preserves the multiplication, for ex lambda = 2:
    f(\lambda * a) = f(2*[0,1]) = f([0,2]) = [0,2]
    Which is the same as :
    f(\lambda * a) = \lambda * f(a) = 2 * [0,1] = [0,2]

\end{align*}\] $$
